seo.title: Positano on a Budget: Practical Guide
seo.description: How to enjoy Positano affordably: transport, cheap eats, free views, budget stays, and money-saving tips.

intro: Stretch your euros by pairing car-free transport, budget eats, and free viewpoints without missing Positano’s highlights.

sections.title: Transport on the cheap
body: Use the Alibus or Curreri shuttle to Sorrento then the SITA bus to Positano; buy bus tickets in blocks from tabacchi to avoid mark-ups.
When seas are calm, mix one ferry leg with buses for comfort—reserve only the segments you need so you don’t overpay.

sections.title: Smart stays
body: Book hostel dorms or shared apartments near Chiesa Nuova to cut porter fees and stair climbs.
Consider bases in Meta or Praiano for longer trips—the commute is 30–40 minutes but rooms are far cheaper in peak season.

sections.title: Food & drink savings
body: Grab panini, sfogliatelle, and espresso from bars instead of sit-down brunch; refill a 1 L (34 oz) bottle at hostel taps before heading out.
Share antipasti, skip cover charges by choosing casual trattorias, and picnic on terraces with deli buys at sunset.

sections.title: Low-cost experiences
body: Plan free hikes like the Path of the Gods (bus to Nocelle) or sunset walks along Via Cristoforo Colombo.
Spend on one standout activity—maybe a shared boat tour or cooking class—and balance the rest with beach days and viewpoints.

tips: Travel in shoulder months (April–May, late September) for lower prices and easier ferry seats.
Track expenses in a notes app; splitting shared costs daily keeps groups aligned.

faqs.q: What daily budget should I plan?
a: €70–€90 covers dorm bed, meals from delis, bus tickets, and one paid activity; add €20–€30 if you prefer private rooms or sunset drinks.
Service is included; round up €1–€2 for great service or leave 10% in upscale venues only if you feel the experience warranted it.
